availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This manuscript contains a draft version of the poem "The Wallabout Martyrs" first published in the New York Herald, March 16, 1888. A note at the bottom states: "sent to Herald March 11" indicating the draft was likely completed around the time of publication. On the verso of the leaves appear scraps of a letter and an envelope addressed to Whitman in Camden.

uva.00518 documents the verso of this text's pages, appears to be correspondence Whitman wrote on the back of

body.head: The Wallabout Martyrs
body.p: [In Brooklyn in an old vault lie huddled at this moment the undoubtedly authentic remains of many thousand of the staunchest and earliest‸Revolutionary patriots, from the British prison⹀ships and prisons of the Revolutionary times of 1776⹀'83 in and around New York; originally buried‸—many thousands of them— in trenches in the Wallabout sands.]

lg.l:
SomeThose car loads of‸old‸charnel ashes dust, mould, scales
and splints of bones,

Once living men—once resolute
courage, aspiration, strength
The stepping⹀stones to thee to-day‸and here America.

Greater by far to thee than
tomb of Alexander,

More, more than memory of
Achilles and Ulysses,

Greater than memory of Achilles
or Ulysses,

More, more by far to thee than
tomb of Alexander,
